Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Disentangling the roles of neighboring plant density and palatability in providing associational defense against herbivory within different habitat types
Award.AbstractNarration:
Herbivory can have large effects on the survival, growth, and reproduction of plants in nature, and the amount of herbivory on a plant can be influenced by its neighboring plants. On the one hand, a plant with more palatable neighbors might be eaten less if herbivores choose to eat its neighbors instead. On the other hand, a plant with a higher density of equally palatable neighbors might be eaten more if herbivores are more attracted to patches where food is more plentiful. Either effect might be modified by the overall level of herbivory in a habitat. This project will experimentally test the effects of density and palatability of neighbors in two types of habitats where rates of herbivory differ, longleaf pine woodlands that have or have not been cultivated in the past. Results will increase our basic understanding of the individual factors that underlie the indirect effects of one plant on another through herbivory.

The broader impacts of this project include applications to restoration of natural habitats and to control of crop damage in agriculture. Restoration of forests on abandoned farm fields can fail because of overlooked factors such as herbivory, and this research takes place in a critically endangered ecosystem of the southeastern U.S. Neighboring plants have been used to deter herbivory in agricultural systems, and results may show how to improve deterrence and thus yields. Findings will be presented to land managers. The project will also train a Ph.D. student and two undergraduate students in ecological research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined how the choice of available plants can change the foraging behavior of insect herbivores (grasshoppers). When given an option between two food types, an herbivore will generally select to feed on the most palatable food item. Thus, the selected food item will depend on the other option presented to the herbivore. In natural ecosystems, plants grow next to a wide variety of neighbors, and the neighbors that any one plant associates with can affect how likely that plant is to be attacked by herbivores (these are called "associational effects"). The research team for this project, consisting of a professor, a graduate student, and two undergraduate students in collaboration with the US Forest Service, designed a series of experiments to gain a better understanding of how various planting schemes affected the likelihood that certain plants of interest would be attacked by herbivores. The results from a field experiment (Figure 1) and a greenhouse experiment (Figure 2) supported the idea that a palatable plant experienced fewer attacks when it is surrounded by a less palatable plant. Essentially the unpalatable plant acted as a repellent and provided protection to the more palatable plant. The reverse was also true, where the less palatable plant also experienced fewer attacks when it was rare, but this was because the herbivores preferentially consumed the more palatable plant.

This area of research has many important implications for understanding patterns of biodiversity in natural ecosystems, as well as in managed ecosystems such as prairie restorations or agricultural systems. For instance, if a land manager is attempting to restore a rare but palatable plant, careful consideration of the neighboring plants (either existing plants or other restored plants) could have beneficial effects on the success of the rare plant. The potential of using neighboring plants to facilitate the restoration of rare plants are particularly relevant to the results of this project, because it was conducted in an endangered ecosystem: the longleaf pine savanna in the southeastern United States (Figure 3). The findings from this study were discussed with scientists and land managers and may be incorporated into future restoration projects.
